['Daffodil - A flower, not closely related to heather but also used in gardens and wild areas.', 'Erica - This is a genus of flowering plants that includes many species often referred to as heathers.', 'Hebe - Another plant with evergreen shrubs similar to some types of heather', 'Echium - A genus including the towering "Pride of Madeira", which resembles a giant spike of heather-like flowers.', 'Calluna - The true heathers, also known as ling or common heather.', 'Juniperus - Some species have a similar appearance to small shrubs like heather and their berries are sometimes hoarded by birds.', 'Genista - A genus of flowering plants in the legume family that includes some evergreen shrubby types.', 'Broom - Another term for certain species within the Genisteae tribe, resembling small bushes like heather.', 'Cedar - Some cedars are low-growing and can appear similar to heathers in texture and structure.', 'Cotoneaster - A genus of shrubs with some species that have a similar compact growth habit as heather.', 'Laburnum (anagram: munblar) - While not closely related, these small trees can sometimes resemble shrubby heathers in form.', 'Myrtus - The genus includes plants like myrtle which share the evergreen characteristic of many heather-like shrubs.', 'Sagebrush - Although much larger than true heathers, sagebrush can give a similar feel with its woody appearance and silver foliage.', 'Pyracantha - Commonly known as firethorn; some of these can grow in forms resembling dense shrubs like heather.', 'Lavender - Some lavenders, particularly the dwarf varieties, have a growth habit similar to heathers and are often used similarly in gardens.', 'Rosemary (anagram: oremyres) - An evergreen herb that can be pruned into dense shrubby forms somewhat reminiscent of heather.', 'Euonymus - This genus includes various decorative shrubs, some with a growth form similar to dwarf heathers.', 'Acanthus (anagram: thanac) - Includes shrubs that can have spiny leaves and a compact shape like some types of heather.', 'Mugo Pine (Pinus mugo) - Though coniferous, in younger plants it can appear as low-growing, bushy forms somewhat similar to heather patches.', 'Heathland - This term refers to the habitat often associated with heathers; though not a plant itself, it represents areas where heathers and similar shrubs dominate.']
